results.name: Least number of squares that add up to n.
comment: Lagrange's "Four Squares theorem" states that a(n) <= 4.
It is easy to show that this is also the least number of squares that add up to n^3.

a(n) = number of iterations in f(...f(f(n))...) to reach 0, where f(n) = A262678(n) = n - A262689(n)^2. Allows computation of this sequence without Lagrange's theorem. - _Antti Karttunen_, Sep 09 2016

formula: a(0) = 0; and for n >= 1, if A010052(n) = 1 [when n is square], a(n) = 1, otherwise, if A229062(n)=1, then a(n) = 2, otherwise a(n) = 3 + A072401(n). [After _Charles R Greathouse IV_'s PARI-program.]
a(0) = 0; for n >= 1, a(n) = 1 + a(n - A262689(n)^2), (see comments).
maple: if nops(select(t -> t[1] mod 4 = 3 and t[2]::odd, ifactors(n)[2])) = 0 then return 2 fi;
if x mod 8 = 7 then 4 else 3 fi
mathematica: SquareCnt[n_] := If[SquaresR[1, n] > 0, 1, If[SquaresR[2, n] > 0, 2, If[SquaresR[3, n] > 0, 3, 4]]]; Table[SquareCnt[n], {n, 150}] (* _T. D. Noe_, Apr 01 2011 *)
sc[n_]:=Module[{s=SquaresR[Range[4],n]},If[First[s]>0,1,Length[ First[ Split[ s]]]+1]]; Join[{0},Array[sc,110]] (* _Harvey P. Dale_, May 21 2014 *)
